fields.label_text:
16. BEER POT
Tin-glazed earthenware, Dutch or German,
English silver-gilt mounts
Unmarked, around 1600
The brilliant blue ceramic is known as Malling ware (from Malling, Kent) because of a well-known piece (now in the British Museum) discovered in a local church. The silver mounts are poor quality and may have been transferred. They incorporate skulls as a reminder to the drinker of the brevity of life's pleasures.
144-1894

JUG
Enamelled earthenware mounted in silver-gilt, stamped and repoussé.
The pottery PERSIAN; 16th century.
The mounts ENGLISH; about 1560. (No marks.)
Bought, £37.16s.   144-1894

fields.descriptive_line: Earthenware pot with turquoise glaze with silver-gilt mounts (unmarked), the pot Dutch or English, 1625-1650; the mounts English, 1600-20.
fields.physical_description: Pot of earthenware with a turquoise glaze; silver-gilt mounts (the gilding worn or absent) on the foot-ring and lip, the handle with a silver thumbpiece in the form of two mermaids, the lid chased with bunches of fruit interspersed with four embossed skulls.
fields.dimensions: Height: 16 cm base to top of finial on closed lid, Width: 11.5 cm body of pot including handle, Weight: 330 g
fields.label:
16. BEER POT
Tin-glazed earthenware, Dutch or German,
English silver-gilt mounts
Unmarked, around 1600
The brilliant blue ceramic is known as Malling ware (from Malling, Kent) because of a well-known piece (now in the British Museum) discovered in a local church. The silver mounts are poor quality and may have been transferred. They incorporate skulls as a reminder to the drinker of the brevity of life's pleasures.
144-1894 [1990]
JUG
Enamelled earthenware mounted in silver-gilt, stamped and repoussé.
The pottery PERSIAN; 16th century.
The mounts ENGLISH; about 1560. (No marks.)
Bought, £37.16s.   144-1894 [1907]
fields.public_access_description:
Between the 1520s and 1600s it was particularly fashionable in England to embellish stone- or earthenware tankards with silver lids and mounts. The tankards, referred to in contemporary texts as 'pots' or 'jugs', were relatively inexpensive; adding silver mounts increased their value and aesthetic appeal. However, even the modest amount of silver needed for this would have been unaffordable to the average day-labourer. In the 1550s, the silver alone for such mounts would have cost around £2 while a journeyman's wage was around a shilling a day (about 5p in modern British currency).
The skull motifs on the lid of this example are unusual: many tankard lids of this date are embossed with leaf or flower patterns, or with designs inspired by Classical ornament. The mounts do not quite fit the rim of the pot (they are abruptly cut away at either side of the handle and thumb-piece, where it would be more usual for them to be joined), which suggests they may have been transferred from the original vessel. This is supported by the appearance of the pot itself. The turquoise colour and glossy surface finish of the glaze suggest a date no earlier than the late seventeenth century and therefore much later than the mounts.
fields.bibliography: Glanville, Philippa. <u>Silver in Tudor and Early Stuart England. A social history and catalogue of the National Collection. 1480-1660</u>. London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 1990. ISBN 1851770305
